name: Sack of Rome (410)
summary: The Sack of Rome by the Visigoths under Alaric I in 410 AD was a pivotal event that shocked the Roman world. It was the first time in nearly 800 years that Rome had been captured by a foreign enemy. This event had profound psychological and theological implications, leading Augustine to write 'The City of God' in response to claims that Christianity had weakened Rome.

name: Nestorian Controversy
summary: The Nestorian controversy was a major theological dispute in the 5th century over the nature of Christ. Nestorius, Patriarch of Constantinople, objected to calling Mary 'Theotokos' (God-bearer), preferring 'Christotokos' (Christ-bearer). This was condemned at the Council of Ephesus (431), leading to a schism with the Church of the East.

name: Monophysite Controversy
summary: Monophysitism was a Christological heresy that held that Christ has only one nature (divine), rather than two natures (divine and human) in one person. This was condemned at the Council of Chalcedon (451), which affirmed the orthodox doctrine of the hypostatic union. The controversy led to schisms with several Eastern churches.

name: Fall of the Western Roman Empire
summary: The fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD, when the last Western Roman Emperor Romulus Augustulus was deposed by Odoacer, marked the end of ancient Rome and the beginning of the Middle Ages. This event had profound consequences for the Church, which would become the primary institution preserving Roman culture and civilization in the West.

name: Council of Ephesus
summary: The Council of Ephesus was the third ecumenical council, convened in 431 AD by Emperor Theodosius II. It condemned Nestorianism and affirmed that Mary is 'Theotokos' (God-bearer), confirming the unity of Christ's person. The council was presided over by Cyril of Alexandria and played a crucial role in defining orthodox Christology.

name: Council of Chalcedon
summary: The Council of Chalcedon was the fourth ecumenical council, held in 451 AD. It defined the orthodox doctrine of the two natures of Christ (divine and human) in one person, using Pope Leo I's 'Tome of Leo' as a key document. The council condemned both Nestorianism and Monophysitism, establishing the Chalcedonian Definition that remains the standard of orthodoxy. Over 520 bishops attended, making it the largest and best-documented of the first seven ecumenical councils.
